prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's delight, now scattered to the wind.
Time's ruthless march has come to thus destroy
The tender bonds that once our souls did bind.

I watched you grow beneath the summer sky,
Your laughter like the sweetest morning song.
But now the hour of parting draws so nigh,
And I must bear this burden and be strong.

The empty spaces echo with your name,
The silent rooms still hold your fading trace.
No candle burns with such a brilliant flame
As did your spirit in this humble place.

Though distance stretches vast between us now,
My love remains, eternal as my vow.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Into the world you venture, brave and free.
The years I've kept you safe within my fold
Now end as you become what you must be.

Remember how I taught you stars by name,
And how we chased the sunset's fading light?
No parent's pride could ever burn more bright
Than mine when first you conquered fear and shame.

The universe awaits your gentle touch,
It yearns to feel your footsteps on its soil.
Though tears now stain the fabric of my soul,
I would not keep you from your destined toil.

So go, beloved child, with my blessing go,
And carry light to places I'll not know.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My flesh and blood, now ashes in the earth.
Death came so swift, a thief in darkest night,
And stole away what gave my life its worth.

The cradle empty, toys untouched and still,
Your absence haunts each corner of this home.
The silence weighs like mountains on my chest,
As through these hollow halls I blindly roam.

What cruel design takes youth before its bloom?
What purpose served in snuffing out your light?
The questions echo through my broken heart,
As day surrenders helplessly to night.

Yet in my dreams, I feel your hand in mine,
Across the veil, our souls forever twine.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A father's verse for one who shaped his soul.
Like Jonson mourning his beloved boy,
I too must face a heart no longer whole.

The printed page preserves what time erodes,
These words a monument when stone has failed.
Through meter, rhyme, and carefully crafted odes,
Your essence lives though mortal flesh has paled.

The poet's gift: to capture grief in art,
Transforming pain to beauty's lasting form.
What language fails to speak from broken heart,
The muse may whisper through the raging storm.

So rest, dear child, immortal in these lines,
Your memory safe as long as language shines.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Creation of my mind and heart combined.
The poem I crafted through nights and days,
Now sent to world beyond my close confines.

Each verse and stanza born of careful thought,
Each metaphor a piece of who I am.
The ink still fresh upon the waiting page,
The words still humming with their gentle psalm.

What readers will you find, what eyes will see
The hidden meanings woven through your form?
Will strangers understand the parts of me
That shelter in your lines when tempests storm?

Go forth, dear work, and carry what is true—
In setting free my words, I'm freed anew.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now departed far.
Like autumn leaves that dance and then deploy
Into the waiting arms of evening star.

I held you once, so small within my palm,
Your fingers wrapped around my weathered thumb.
Your laughter was my spirit's sweetest balm,
Your whispers, songs to which my soul succumbed.

The world has claimed you, as it always must,
Drawn you away on currents swift and strong.
I stand here rooted, watching turns of dust
That mark your path, now where you belong.

Yet in this parting, painful though it be,
I find strange comfort knowing you are free.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Scion of hope, now venturing alone.
Time's cruel current carries thee away,
Leaving me here with memories to atone.

The cradle empty, silent is your room,
Footsteps no longer echo down the hall.
Your absence blooms like winter's darkest gloom,
Yet pride wells up behind my sorrow's wall.

For what is love if not the strength to loose
The tethers binding you to sheltered shore?
What father worthy would his grip refuse
To slacken, letting you seek something more?

So fly, my child, on wings I helped to build,
And know my heart, with love, remains fulfilled.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My flesh and blood now scattered to the wind.
The universe reclaims what I enjoyed—
A borrowed blessing, never mine to bind.

I watch you fade like stars at break of day,
Your brilliance lingering in my mind's eye.
Though distance grows with each step on your way,
Our souls remain entangled, you and I.

Remember lessons whispered in the dark,
The stories told beside your fevered bed.
Carry my voice when doubt leaves its stark mark,
Unfold my wisdom when your own has fled.

This parting writes its anguish on my face,
Yet launches you toward your rightful place.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Beneath the weight of years we now must part.
The universe conspires in its ploy
To separate what's dearest to my heart.

I've watched you grow from seedling into tree,
Your branches reaching toward the endless sky.
The roots I nurtured now set you free
To weather storms without my standing by.

The chalice of my grief runs overflowing,
Yet mingles with the sweetest pride I've known.
For in your eyes, I see your future glowing—
A light more brilliant than I've ever shown.

So go, beloved, chase horizons new,
My love remains your compass, strong and true.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The clock strikes out our final hour together.
Like ships at dawn, our paths must now deploy
To separate horizons, changing weather.

I held your beginnings in trembling hands,
Witnessed first steps, first words, first heartaches too.
I built you shelters, drew maps across lands,
Never thinking how swift the years flew through.

Now standing tall where once you barely reached,
You carry portions of my soul away.
The lessons that I struggled to have teached
Become your armor for another day.

Though distance grows between our beating hearts,
Love's invisible thread never truly parts.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Shadow that danced upon the morning light,
Small fingers that once held my world entire,
Now scattered like stars across heaven's night.

I watched you grow from whisper into song,
From fragile bud to flower fully blown.
The seasons of your life passed swift as clouds,
And now the wind has claimed what I had sown.

How strange that love can feel like burning coal,
That glows more fiercely as it turns to ash.
I hold the memory of your laughing face,
As time flows forward in relentless dash.

Farewell, sweet child, though parting breaks my heart,
Your spirit lives in every breath I start.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Into the mist of memory you fade,
Like autumn leaves that cling, then drift away,
Returning to the soil where dreams are laid.

The echo of your footsteps haunts these halls,
While silence grows where laughter used to bloom.
I trace your shadow on the empty walls,
As twilight paints its colors through the room.

What hand of fate has pulled you from my grasp?
What distant shore now claims your tender heart?
The universe expands between our souls—
A vast and star-strewn canvas torn apart.

Yet in this ache, a truth begins to shine:
Though parted now, you'll always remain mine.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My pen falls silent where once verses flowed.
The ink runs dry, like tears upon the page,
As grief carves pathways where our love once showed.

I crafted worlds for you from simple words,
Built castles high with rhyme and metered line.
But now those towers crumble into dust,
As death, that thief, steals what was wholly mine.

The cosmos shifts; the planets realign,
The sun seems dimmer in the morning sky.
The birds still sing, though dissonant and strange,
As if they too must learn to say goodbye.

Yet even as the darkness claims its due,
I find immortal light residing in you.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The vessel of my hopes now set adrift
Upon the boundless ocean of the years,
Your absence is both punishment and gift.

I see you in the dandelion seeds,
That scatter when the gentlest breeze takes flight.
In raindrops racing down the windowpane,
In fireflies that punctuate the night.

How curious that distance can reveal
The magnitude of love I bear for thee.
Like mountains that grow taller when beheld
From miles away across a churning sea.

Though parting cleaves my spirit like a blade,
The love we shared shall nevermore fade.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Beneath the weight of time we must now bend.
The hourglass empties, grain by falling grain,
As all beginnings journey toward their end.

I taught your hands to form their letters true,
To trace the constellations in night skies.
Now you depart to chart your own bright stars,
With wisdom gleaming in your searching eyes.

The garden where I watched your spirit grow
Stands empty now, yet blooms with memory.
Each flower holds the laughter of those days,
Each thorn reminds of love's sweet agony.

Go forth, dear heart, though parting brings such pain—
In leaving me, yourself you now reclaim.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Departing spirit, flickering like a flame,
You danced among us for too brief a stay,
Your laughter echoing through empty halls.

The cradle rocks, abandoned now and still,
Where once your breathing marked the hours of night.
I trace your shadow on the nursery wall,
And catch your scent on blankets, growing faint.

How strange that something so small in form
Could leave a void so vast within my chest.
The world continues in its mindless spin,
While I am anchored to this grief, unmoved.

The seasons change, and you will never see
The blossoms burst or autumn's golden hue.
Yet in each petal, each descending leaf,
I'll seek your face, your spirit lingering still.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now beyond my reach.
The stars have claimed you for their silent realm,
Leaving me here with memories and dust.

What cosmic force demanded your return
Before your story barely had begun?
The ink still wet upon your opening page,
The book now closed, its promise unfulfilled.

I search for meaning in this emptiness,
For purpose in the pain that fills my days.
Perhaps you were too perfect for this world,
A glimpse of heaven not meant to remain.

So fly, my child, beyond the veil of tears,
Where suffering and sorrow cannot reach.
And I shall carry forward in your name,
Until the day our souls again entwine.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My flesh and blood, now scattered to the wind.
The garden where I planted all my hopes
Lies barren now beneath a winter sky.

I held you close against the coming storm,
Yet could not shield you from its savage breath.
The universe, indifferent to our love,
Reclaimed its gift with cold, unfeeling hands.

What use are words against this tidal grief?
What comfort can mere language hope to bring?
Yet still I speak your name into the void,
As if my voice might somehow bring you home.

Remember me, as I remember you,
Across whatever distance now divides.
For love transcends the boundaries of time,
And binds us still, though worlds may intervene.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The light that guided me through darkest nights.
How swiftly came the shadow of the end,
How quietly it stole you from my sight.

I stand beside the river of my tears,
Watching your vessel vanish with the tide.
No map exists to chart your journey now,
No compass points the way for me to follow.

The world speaks on in meaningless routine,
As if the sun still rises as before.
Do they not see the colors have all changed?
The music muted, flavors turned to ash?

Yet in this gray and hollow aftermath,
I feel your presence like a phantom limb.
Perhaps in dreams we'll meet on distant shores,
Where love defies the boundaries of death.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My morning star, extinguished far too soon.
I carved your name upon my beating heart,
A testament to love that cannot die.

The clocks tick on, indifferent to my loss,
As if the world has not been torn apart.
I move among the living like a ghost,
Half-here, half-following where you have gone.

They tell me time will dull this cutting edge,
That memories will comfort, not destroy.
Perhaps one day I'll hold your absence close
Without this drowning wave of grief renewed.

Until that distant dawn, I'll guard your light,
The echo of your laughter, touch, and smile.
And though you've journeyed far beyond my reach,
You live forever in this broken heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Whose laughter echoed through these hollow halls,
Now silent as the grave that claims your form.
I stand bereft, a shadow of myself,
Clutching memories like autumn leaves—
Brilliant, fragile, fading with each breath.

You were the light that guided weary steps,
The compass of my heart through darkest storms.
Now stars collapse, and oceans cease to flow,
As I surrender what I cannot keep.

How strange that flesh of flesh should part so soon,
That time, so generous in pain, should steal
The precious hours we thought were guaranteed.
I trace your name in dust and morning dew,
And plant your memory where flowers grow.

Farewell, sweet child, though parting breaks my soul—
You journey where I cannot follow yet.
But in the silence of each dusk and dawn,
I'll seek your whisper on the passing wind,
And hold your absence like a treasured gift.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
So swiftly carried on time's ruthless tide.
The cradle rocks, now empty of your form,
While I, the broken vessel, still remain.

What cosmic debt demanded payment thus?
What heavenly account required your soul?
The ledger of my heart shows only loss,
Where once abundance overflowed with grace.

I watched you bloom like spring's first hesitant bud,
Unfurling petals toward the warming sun.
Too brief your season in this garden harsh,
Too quick the frost that stole your vibrant hue.

The world spins on, indifferent to my grief,
As stars continue their celestial dance.
Yet in their light, I sometimes glimpse your smile,
A constellation formed of memory.

So rest, beloved, in that distant shore,
Where pain dissolves like mist at break of day.
And I shall carry forward what remains—
The love that death, with all its might, cannot erase.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My quill trembles as I pen these words,
Ink mixing with tears upon the page.

You were the verse I never thought to write,
A sonnet formed of flesh and beating heart,
More beautiful than any art I've known.
Now torn from life's great manuscript too soon,
Leaving chapters unfinished, stories untold.

The garden where we walked lies overgrown,
Your favorite flowers nodding in the breeze,
As if they too mourn your swift departure.
The apple tree still bears its yearly fruit,
Though no small hands reach up to pluck them now.

I search for meaning in this sudden void,
For purpose in the pain that fills my days.
Perhaps you were a lesson briefly lent,
A masterclass in love's transforming power.

Though distance grows between our separate worlds,
I feel you near in every breath I take.
Farewell, sweet child—not goodbye, but merely
A pause before our stories join again.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The universe grows dimmer with your leave.
No longer shall I witness morning's light
Reflected in your eyes of innocent wonder,
Nor hear your footsteps racing down the hall.

You were the anchor to my drifting ship,
The compass guiding me through stormy seas.
Now rudderless, I face the vast unknown,
With only memory's lantern lighting paths
Where once we walked in perfect harmony.

The seasons change without your witness now;
Spring blossoms fall on ground you'll never touch.
The summer sun warms skin you've shed like dreams,
And autumn leaves cascade in flames of gold,
Reminiscent of your spirit's burning bright.

I gather fragments of our shattered time—
A half-read book, a toy abandoned mid-play,
A tiny handprint pressed in hardened clay—
And build a shrine to what can never be,
A monument to love that transcends death.

Farewell, dear heart, though parting rends my soul;
In every breath, your essence lingers still.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
How cruel the fates that sever sacred bonds.
The clock ticks forward with relentless pace,
While memory freezes you in amber light—
Eternal child, forever incomplete.

I search the heavens for your distant sign,
Some constellation bearing your sweet name.
Perhaps that brightest star that pierces night
Is but the gleaming of your radiant soul,
Still watching over those you left behind.

The house stands quiet where your laughter rang,
Each room a museum of what was lost.
I wander halls like some forgotten ghost,
Collecting echoes of your vanished self,
Preserving moments time cannot reclaim.

What lessons hide within this bitter cup?
What wisdom waits beyond the veil of tears?
Perhaps to love completely is enough,
To give oneself without reserve or fear,
Despite the knowledge all must end in loss.

So farewell, precious child of heart and hope;
Though severed from my sight, not from my soul.
In dreams we meet upon that distant shore
Where partings cease and joy knows no more end.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Shadow of promise, now fading to dust.
Time's cruel passage I cannot destroy,
As you slip away, as all things must.

In your eyes I glimpsed eternity's light,
A flame too perfect for this world to hold.
Now darkness gathers, turning day to night,
Your story unfinished, yet fully told.

I placed my hopes upon your tender frame,
Dreamed futures bright beyond the veil of years.
The universe has no place for blame,
Only this hollow space to catch my tears.

So go, sweet child, into that distant peace,
While I remain to watch the stars increase.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My little songbird, wings spread wide and free.
No longer nestled in my warm employ,
But soaring skyward, as it's meant to be.

I crafted you from midnight whispers, dear,
From fragments of my soul and morning light.
Your journey calls, though I would keep you near,
I must release you to your rightful flight.

The world awaits with both its thorns and blooms,
To teach you lessons I could never share.
My love follows through sunlit days and glooms,
A silent guardian floating on the air.

Go forth, beloved, seek your distant star,
Remember home awaits, however far.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Departed ember of a once-bright flame.
The cosmic dance continues to employ
Its ancient rhythms, never quite the same.

I held you briefly, like morning holds dew,
A fleeting treasure on time's endless loom.
The universe that gave has taken you,
Returning stardust to its stellar womb.

What words contain the depth of this release?
What language cradles such profound goodbye?
The silence stretches, offering no peace,
Beneath the indifferent, watchful sky.

Yet in this void, your essence still remains,
Transformed, not ended, flowing through my veins.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My creation, my verse, my heart's own beat.
The hours we shared, no time can destroy,
Though now our paths no longer shall meet.

I shaped your form with trembling fingertips,
Breathed life into your being, word by word.
The sweetest phrases falling from my lips,
Creating worlds where your voice could be heard.

How strange to bid farewell to what was born
From deepest chambers of my searching mind.
Yet all creations must face their morn
Of independence, leaving me behind.

So venture forth, no longer mine to keep,
While I return to solitude's vast deep.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
We part now at the crossroads of our tale.
The bonds we forged, no distance can destroy,
Though memory dims and mortal flesh grows pale.

I watched you bloom from tender seed to flower,
A miracle unfolding day by day.
Each moment precious, each fleeting hour
A treasure time too quickly steals away.

The world turns ever onward in its dance,
A rhythm ancient as the stars above.
I release you to fate's uncertain chance,
Armed only with the armor of my love.

Go forth, beloved, seek what lies beyond,
While here I stand, still holding our shared bond.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep
I drift through oceans of forgotten stars,
Where memories dissolve like morning dew
And time suspends its hurried march.

In my first sleep
The world's sharp edges soften,
Mountains bow their heads in reverence
To the silence that precedes all things.

In my first sleep
I am both child and ancient,
Cradled in the arms of what once was
Yet reaching toward what might become.

In my first sleep
Voices whisper from the shadows,
Telling tales of paths not taken,
Of doors left slightly ajar.

In my first sleep
I find the courage that daylight steals,
And walk unburdened through the garden
Of my most tender, hidden truths.

IN MY FIRST SLEEP

In my first sleep I found a door
Beneath the pillow's gentle fold,
A passage through the conscious shore
To realms where myths and dreams unfold.

In my first sleep the clock unwound
Its ticking hands and numbered face.
I floated free, no longer bound
By gravity or time or space.

In my first sleep I met myself—
A child with weathered, knowing eyes,
Who held my fears upon a shelf
And spoke in ancient lullabies.

In my first sleep the world reversed;
The stars grew roots, trees touched the moon.
The ocean's depths became the sky,
And winter bloomed in sudden June.

In my first sleep I understood
The language written in my bones—
A wisdom deeper than the blood
That makes these borrowed cells my own.

In my first sleep

I surrendered to the void
like a petal falling into dark water,
neither fighting nor embracing
the descent into that other country.

In my first sleep
the boundaries dissolved—
human and animal,
living and dead,
the self I claimed and the self
I had always denied.

In my first sleep
I heard my grandmother's voice
though she passed before my birth,
her words like polished stones
dropped into the well of my being.

In my first sleep
I walked through doorways
that daylight renders invisible,
traced the outlines of possibilities
that reason would dismiss.

In my first sleep
I remembered everything—
the taste of creation,
the sound before sound,
the light before light,
and the great forgetting that followed.

IN MY FIRST SLEEP

In my first sleep I found myself adrift
Between the shores of consciousness and dream,
Where shadows dance and phantom memories shift,
And nothing is exactly as it seems.

The weight of day had melted from my bones,
Released me from the prison of my skin.
I wandered through cathedrals made of stones
That whispered all the places I had been.

In my first sleep, I met the stranger's face
That lives behind the mask I daily wear.
We recognized each other in that place
Where truth cannot be hidden or impaired.

The universe contracted to a pearl,
Then expanded to encompass all of time.
I watched galaxies collapse and unfurl
In patterns more mysterious than rhyme.

In my first sleep, I touched eternity,
Then woke with just the faintest memory.

In my first sleep

The world unravels like a spool of thread,
Each moment I have lived becomes undone.
The tapestry of day hangs by a shred
As consciousness surrenders to the none.

In my first sleep, I shed the skin of thought,
Becoming formless as the midnight air.
The battles that my waking hours fought
Dissolve like mist—both victory and despair.

In my first sleep, ancestral voices sing
Of times before my body claimed its name.
I feel the pull of that primeval spring
From which all dreams and dreaming bodies came.

In my first sleep, I am both less and more
Than what the mirror shows in morning light—
A traveler between the twin-faced shore
Where day meets dark, where wrong encounters right.

In my first sleep, I finally understand
That I am but a breath between two voids.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, the world dissolved away,
Leaving only dreams to paint the night,
Whispers of forgotten childhood days,
Dancing shadows in the pale moonlight.

In my first sleep, I traveled far and wide,
To realms where logic holds no sway,
Where rivers flow through starlit skies,
And mountains breathe at break of day.

In my first sleep, I met my younger self,
Wide-eyed and full of boundless hope,
Reminding me of promises I'd made,
Before the weight of years began to cope.

In my first sleep, the universe revealed
Its secrets in a language pure and true,
Only to fade like morning dew,
When dawn's first light came breaking through.

In my first sleep I wandered deep
Beneath the veil where shadows keep
The secrets of the ancient stars
And memories of healing scars.

In my first sleep I heard the call
Of voices through the darkened hall
Of consciousness suspended high
Between the earth and endless sky.

The universe in infant state
Unfolded like a garden gate
Revealing paths I'd never known
And truths I'd never been shown.

In my first sleep I felt the touch
Of everything I'd missed so much—
The gentle hands of those now gone
Still guiding me through dusk to dawn.

In my first sleep, I found the key
To who I was and who I'd be
A sacred space where time stood still
And dreams flowed free against my will.

In my first sleep, darkness cradles me
Like mother's arms, familiar yet strange.
I drift between worlds, neither here nor there,
A traveler suspended in the void of night.

In my first sleep, memories crystallize
Into diamond-sharp visions of what was,
What could have been, what might yet be—
Possibilities bloom like midnight flowers.

The clock ticks somewhere in the waking world,
But here, time bends and folds upon itself.
I am both child and elder, novice and sage,
Navigating the labyrinth of unconscious thought.

In my first sleep, I shed the skin of day,
All pretenses dissolved in slumber's alchemy.
I face my truest self in this twilight realm
Where honesty cannot hide behind waking masks.

When morning comes, I will return changed,
Carrying fragments of dreams like precious stones,
Treasures from that borderland where
In my first sleep, I briefly touched eternity.

In my first sleep, the cosmos opens wide
A doorway to the chambers of the mind
Where ancient wisdom, long since set aside
Awakens what the daylight left behind.

The ticking clock dissolves to timeless space
As consciousness slips into deeper seas
Where thought and form exchange their rightful place
And logic bows to strange geometries.

The burdens that I carried through the day
Transform to birds with iridescent wings
That carry me along their skyward way
To witness how the universe still sings.

In this first realm between the dark and light
I glimpse the truths that hide from waking sight—
How all our separate stories intertwine
Like constellations in the vault divine.

In my first sleep, I briefly understand
The patterns woven through our mortal lives
Before dawn pulls me back to solid land
Where only echoes of the dream survive.

In my first sleep, I found a garden wild
With flowers no waking eye has ever seen,
Their petals made of whispers, soft and mild,
Their stems of memories, both sharp and keen.

The moon hung low, a silver pendant there,
Illuminating paths of scattered thought,
While stars like breadcrumbs led me everywhere
To treasures that my conscious mind had sought.

The shadows danced with purpose, not with threat,
Companions on this journey through the deep,
Revealing truths I struggle to forget
When daylight breaks the spell of my first sleep.

I heard the voices of the ones I've lost
Speaking clearly through the veil of years,
Their wisdom offered freely, without cost,
Their laughter drying all my unshed tears.

In my first sleep, I am both old and young,
A paradox of what was and will be,
The sweetest songs are those as yet unsung
In that brief space where dreams have set me free.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, I wander through meadows,
Where dreams like butterflies flutter and dance.
The world is hushed, reality shadows,
As consciousness slips into trance.

Soft whispers of forgotten memories rise,
Cradled by night's gentle, velvet embrace.
Stars spill their secrets across darkened skies,
Time slows its hurried, relentless pace.

In my first sleep, I am both child and sage,

Free from the constraints of earthly cage,
I float where thought need not stand tall.

Here, in this realm between worlds suspended,
I taste the freedom of uncharted seas.
Where beginnings and endings are blended,
And I am, at last, completely free.

In my first sleep, the universe unfolds
Like origami stars in midnight blue.
A symphony of silence that holds
The weight of dreams both false and true.

I drift through corridors of ancient light,
Where memories not yet lived take shape.
The boundary thins between day and night,
As consciousness begins to escape.

Voices echo from a distant shore,
Familiar yet impossible to place.
A language I've never heard before,
Yet understand with natural grace.

In my first sleep, I am ageless, whole,
A traveler between what is and might be.
The first true journey of the soul,
Before the dawn breaks cruelly free.

In my first sleep, the world dissolves away
Like sugar crystals in a warm spring rain.
The clocks all stop, the minutes cease to play,
And what was solid now seems thin and plain.

The walls that guard my waking thoughts recede,
Permitting wild imaginings to bloom.
Unchained from logic, reason, thought, or creed,
My mind expands beyond its daylight room.

Colors never seen by waking eyes
Paint landscapes that defy the laws of space.
Beneath unfathomable foreign skies,
I find a strange but welcoming embrace.

In my first sleep, I touch eternity,
A fleeting glimpse of all that lies beyond.
A sacred, fragile opportunity
To swim in depths of which I'm rarely fond.

In my first sleep, I shed the day's disguise,
The mask I wear through hours of light and noise.
The person I pretend, the compromise,
All fade as deeper consciousness deploys.

The burdens carried through the waking hours
Dissolve like morning mist on summer hills.
My spirit, freed from its restraining powers,
Expands beyond the borders that it fills.

Here, in this twilight realm of half-formed thought,
Where logic bends and reason takes a bow,
I find the truths that cannot be bought,
And wisdom that the day would not allow.

In my first sleep, I glimpse my truest face,
Unclouded by the judgments of the sun.
I touch the sacred, timeless, boundless space,
Where all that is and was and will be—come as one.

In my first sleep, the ancestors arrive,
Their footsteps gentle on forgotten floors.
They whisper tales of how they lived and thrived,
And open long-abandoned mental doors.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, I wandered through gardens
of memory not yet formed, where shadows dance
like prophecies against the walls of time.
The moon, a silver coin tossed in dark waters,
rippled with dreams I could almost touch.

My mother's voice, distant as childhood,
called from rooms I hadn't entered yet.
My hands were small again, reaching
for doorknobs too high, for meanings
that floated just beyond my grasp.

In my first sleep, I was both ancient and unborn,
a paradox of breath suspended between worlds,
the universe folding itself into the small space
of my chest, expanding with each heartbeat
into constellations I would someday name.

In my first sleep, the world dissolved
like sugar in hot tea, sweetening
the darkness that pooled around me.

I felt myself unraveling,
threads of consciousness pulled loose
by gentle, unseen fingers.

The day's sharp edges softened,
its noises muffled by the thick quilt
of approaching dreams.

I remembered things I never knew—
the taste of stars, the weight of silence,
the color of time before clocks.

In my first sleep, I was neither
here nor gone, but suspended
in that sacred space between,

where the soul slips its moorings
and drifts, untethered,
into the vast, forgiving night.

In my first sleep, ghosts become tangible
wrapping fingers around forgotten toys
and spinning the mobile above my crib
that I swear still turns on windless nights.

The boundary thins between what was
and what might have been—possibilities
shimmer like heat above summer roads.

In my first sleep, I am ageless,
cradled in the arms of ancestral whispers,
rocking to the rhythm of heartbeats
that ceased before mine began.

The universe contracts to the size of a seed,
then expands until I am nothing but breath
dispersed among stars that blink in code.

In my first sleep, I remember everything:
the womb, the light, the fall, the rise,
all mysteries solved then forgotten
with the coming of dawn.

In my first sleep, mountains form
from the blankets' gentle folds,
and rivers run through valleys
of wrinkled cotton sheets.

The pillow, a cloud that carries
my heavy head to places
I've never been awake,
to faces I've never seen.

Time stretches like taffy,
minutes becoming hours,
hours becoming lifetimes
lived between heartbeats.

Words spoken years ago
return with perfect clarity,
and wounds I thought had healed
bleed fresh in the dark.

In my first sleep, I am
both more and less myself,
stripped of pretense yet clothed
in possibilities that daylight
would never dare suggest.

In my first sleep, the universe contracts
to fit within my ribcage, stars pulsing
in rhythm with my slowing heart.

The day's debris—harsh words, missed chances,
small victories—settles like silt
at the bottom of a still pond.

I sink beneath familiar surfaces,
below the person I pretend to be,
into the depths where truth doesn't need words.

Here, in this twilight realm between
wakefulness and deeper dreams,
I meet myself as stranger and as friend.

In my first sleep, I remember what it means
to be unfinished, a draft of a person
still being written by invisible hands.

The pen pauses, the ink dries,
and for these few precious moments,
I exist without explanation or apology.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We are dreamy creature'

responses.text:
We are dreamy creatures
Wandering through mists of thought,
Our minds like galaxies expanding
Beyond the borders of what's taught.

We spin our hopes from stardust,
Weave wishes into night,
Our souls drift between worlds
Where imagination takes flight.

Dreams cascade like waterfalls
Behind our closing eyes,
Reality blends with fantasy
As consciousness softly dies.

We are dreamy creatures,
Never fully here nor there,
Existing in the spaces
Between breath and prayer.

Perhaps that's our true nature—
To live half in, half out
Of this tangible existence,
Forever wrapped in doubt and doubt.

WE ARE DREAMY CREATURES

We are dreamy creatures
with moonlight in our veins,
carrying universes
inside fragile frames.

Our thoughts drift like clouds
across internal skies,
reality and fantasy
blurring as time flies.

We build castles in our minds
where impossible things bloom,
transforming mundane moments
into cosmic sacred rooms.

We are dreamy creatures
sleepwalking through the day,
while our souls dance wildly
in worlds so far away.

Half-anchored to this earth,
half-floating through the stars,
we are living paradoxes—
both prisoners and czars.

We are dreamy creatures,
never fully awake,
forever lost in wonders
that only dreamers make.

We are dreamy creatures,
Soft-edged and undefined,
Shimmering at the borders
Of matter and mind.

Our thoughts like gossamer threads
Spun across the void,
Connecting distant planets
With what we've destroyed.

We walk in two worlds always:
The seen and unseen realm,
Captains of phantom vessels
With no one at the helm.

We are dreamy creatures,
Half-formed and incomplete,
Ever reaching toward horizons
Where sky and ocean meet.

In the spaces between heartbeats,
In the silence after sound,
We glimpse our true reflection—
Neither lost nor found.

We are dreamy creatures,
And perhaps that is enough:
To wander through existence
Made of stardust, light, and love.

We are dreamy creatures
drifting between worlds,
neither here nor there—
our essence gently swirls.

We touch reality
with fingertips so light,
then retreat to shadow realms
at the coming of the night.

Our eyes see double visions:
the world that others know,
and landscapes of pure wonder
where wild ideas grow.

We speak in riddle languages
that logical minds can't hear,
and dance to distant rhythms
that bring both joy and fear.

We are dreamy creatures,
half-formed and incomplete,
yet somehow more authentic
than those who walk concrete.

Perhaps our greatest purpose
is simply this: to show
that life exists in layers
most never come to know.

We are dreamy creatures
With stardust in our eyes,
Not quite of this earth
Nor fully of the skies.

We walk between dimensions,
Feet barely touching ground,
Our minds always wandering
Where mysteries abound.

Reality bends around us
Like light through crystal prisms,
Transforming mundane moments
Into sacred mysticism.

We breathe in possibilities
And exhale new creations,
Our hearts forever pulsing
With cosmic revelations.

Some call us disconnected,
Lost in our reverie,
But we've simply found the doorway
To what others cannot see.

We are dreamy creatures,
Unapologetic and wild,
Preserving ancient magic
With the wonder of a child.

Like water round a stone.
We count our days by moonlight,
Not by clocks or telephones.

We are dreamy creatures,
Collectors of the strange.
We find beauty in shadows
That others would exchange.

So if you meet us walking
On paths where wild things grow,
Join our dreamy wanderings—
There's magic here, you know.

WE ARE DREAMY CREATURES

We are dreamy creatures, born of twilight's glow,
Half-formed thoughts and whispers from the long ago.
Neither flesh nor phantom, dancing on the edge,
Where reality and fantasy seamlessly hedge.

Our footsteps leave no imprints in the morning dew,
Yet mountains move and oceans part at what we do.
We speak through silent symphonies and colored air,
Invisible to those who never truly dare.

We are dreamy creatures with kaleidoscope eyes,
Seeing fractured beauty others can't recognize.
Our hands weave possibilities from thinnest thread,
Bringing life to visions others thought were dead.

Time flows around us like a river round a stone,
We exist in moments others have outgrown.
Catching fragments of forever in our open palms,
Transforming chaos into unexpected calms.

We are dreamy creatures, and perhaps so are you,
If you've ever felt the impossible come true.
Join us in the twilight, where boundaries dissolve,
And the mysteries of existence slowly, sweetly solve.

We are dreamy creatures
Drifting through the void,
Cloaked in starlight veils
That time cannot avoid.

Hands reaching for phantoms,
Eyes fixed on what's not there,
Breathing in possibilities
That shimmer in the air.

We are dreamy creatures
With roots in ancient soil,
Yet branches stretching upward
Beyond earthly toil.

Our hearts beat to rhythms
Of distant, dying suns,
Echoing the music
Where cosmic rivers run.

We are dreamy creatures,
Never fully here—
Always partly wandering
Through realms of hope and fear.

Reality's thin membrane
We pierce with gentle thought,
Finding truths eternal
That cannot be bought.

We are dreamy creatures,
And in this dream we share,
Perhaps we'll find the answers
To questions we don't dare.

MIDNIGHT EXPRESS

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
ABANDONED BY TEARS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like frightened birds, deserting their nest.
Betrayed by my own sorrow, twice denied—
First by joy, then by the tears that should attest.

Even grief refuses me companionship,
Evaporating before it marks my face.
Salt crystals form a temporary crypt,
Then vanish, leaving not a single trace.

Am I so hollow that sadness cannot dwell?
So empty that even pain finds no home here?
My chest heaves with a story it cannot tell,
Dry-eyed in an ocean of unshed fear.

Perhaps true loneliness is not the absence of others,
But when your own emotions become strangers,
When even the wetness of sorrow smothers
Its evidence, and leaves you to your dangers.

WATERLESS MOURNING

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me mid-sorrow, mid-flight,
Drying before they've had their chance to glide
Down cheeks that hunger for their cooling light.

What faithless companions these droplets prove—
Born of my anguish but quick to depart.
They rise like promises from depths of love
Then disappear, traitors to my breaking heart.

The desert of my face bears no wet trails,
No evidence of storms that rage within.
Each silent scream behind my lips still wails
While outward signs of suffering grow thin.

Perhaps I've learned to grieve without a trace,
To hide the rivers flowing through my soul.
Or maybe pain has found a deeper place
Where even tears fear they might lose control.

GHOSTED BY GRIEF

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They vanish like lovers who promised forever,
Leaving no evidence they ever tried
To manifest what I feel, whatsoever.

My body betrays what my heart cannot hide—
A drought in the midst of emotional flood.
These waterless sobs, this tearless tide,
This silent scream trapped in my blood.

What cruel design makes sorrow so dry?
What cosmic joke leaves grief without its rain?
The weight of oceans pressing from inside
With not a single droplet to explain.

Perhaps I've cried so much throughout the years
That I've exhausted all my saline stores.
Or maybe I've evolved beyond mere tears
To something deeper that simply ignores

The ancient language of water and salt,
Speaking instead in trembles and in sighs.
This tearless weeping is nobody's fault—
Just one more way my body tells its lies.

DESERTION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like cowards from a losing war,
Evaporating before they've testified
To what it is my heart is breaking for.

Even my sorrow refuses to be seen,
Dissolving back into the void within.
Leaving my face unnaturally serene
While chaos reigns beneath my plastered skin.

What good is grief that leaves behind no trace?
A phantom pain with no physical scar?
The universe denies me even grace
Of visible proof of how wounded we are.

Perhaps true suffering transcends display,
Perhaps real anguish needs no liquid form.
Or maybe I've just learned to keep at bay
The outward signals of my inward storm.

So here I stand, abandoned by the tears
That should mark passages of human pain.
Left only with these dry and burning fears
And eyes as barren as a world without rain.

INVISIBLE DOWNPOUR

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They're ghosts before they're born, phantoms of pain,
Invisible witnesses to how I've died
A thousand times but somehow still remain.

What strange betrayal of the body's truth—
To feel the surge of sorrow's rising tide
Yet stand with cheeks as dry as ancient ruth,
With all the evidence of grief denied.

Perhaps my sadness is too deep for tears,
Too vast to be contained in drops of salt.
Perhaps I've spent too many hollow years
With emotions locked inside a buried vault.

Or maybe tears, like friends and fleeting love,
Have learned that I'm not worth the time to stay.
They form like morning promises above,
Then disappear before the break of day.

So I remain—abandoned, parched, bereft—
A desert where an ocean should reside,
With nothing but the echo of what's left
When even tears won't linger at my side.

WATERLESS GRIEF

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like startled birds from a sudden noise,
Leaving me alone with the weight of my sorrow.
Even my sadness lacks the courage to show its face.

These phantom tears—invisible companions
That refuse to manifest when summoned,
As if pain too deep becomes its own prison,
Locking away the relief of visible grief.

The world demands proof of suffering.
How do I show them the ocean inside
When it refuses to spill onto shores of skin?

My body betrays me with its dryness,
My heart screams while my eyes remain mute,
As if saying: some wounds run too deep for water,
Some hurts transcend the language of tears.

I am left with only the echo of weeping,
A sadness so complete it has consumed
Even the evidence of itself.

DESERTION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They vanish like promises in the morning light,
Leaving no trace of their brief existence.
Even my grief refuses me companionship.

Is there loneliness more complete
Than when your own sorrow abandons you?
When the physical proof of your breaking
Disappears before it can be witnessed?

I am left standing in a desert of feeling,
Parched with emotion that finds no release,
A wellspring with no water, a rain cloud without rain.

Perhaps this is the final betrayal—
When even the salt-water witnesses to your pain
Refuse to testify, refuse to mark your face,
Refuse to leave evidence that you felt anything at all.

I reach for the comfort of visible grief
But find only the ghost of what should be there,
A dry-eyed sorrow that burns hotter
For having nowhere to go.

TEARLESS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They've learned the art of leaving before they arrive,
Like guests who RSVP then never show,
Leaving me with a feast of grief no one will taste.

How strange to feel the tremor of sobbing
Without the release of falling water,
To experience the earthquake without the flood,
The breaking without the cleansing after.

Perhaps my body has learned too well
The lessons of loss and abandonment—
Even my biological responses have given up on me.

Or maybe this pain runs too deep for tears,
Too vast for such simple expression,
Like trying to drain an ocean with a teaspoon.

So I stand here, dry-eyed and drowning,
Suffocating in the contradiction:
A person weeping without tears,
A storm without rain,
A grief without witness.

VANISHING EVIDENCE

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They evaporate before touching my cheeks,
As if ashamed of their own existence,
Or perhaps afraid of the depth they represent.

My body has become a cemetery of unexpressed grief,
A mausoleum where sadness enters but never leaves,
Where even the simplest proof of feeling
Disappears before it can be catalogued.

I press my fingers to my face, searching
For the dampness that should validate my pain.
Nothing. Not even this small mercy remains.

How cruel that in our darkest moments
We are denied even the physical release,
The tangible evidence that we are human,
That we are breaking, that we are real.

I am left with only the memory of tears,
The ghost of what should be there,
A dry monument to a flood that never came,
A desert where an ocean should be.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# Abandoned by Tears

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They abandon me like friends who've grown tired.
Departing my cheeks in silent betrayal,
Even my sorrow refuses to abide.

These droplets of pain, these liquid goodbyes,
They fall to the earth, rejecting my grief.
Is nothing sacred? Not even the salt
Of my own broken heart remains in my keep.

How strange to be left by the very evidence
Of my own suffering—gone without trace.
The world washes clean what I cannot hold,
Leaving nothing but dry tracks on my face.

Perhaps there's wisdom in their swift retreat,
Teaching me nothing of pain remains permanent.
Even the witnesses to my deepest wounds
Know when it's time to depart and relent.

# Desertion

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They rush down my face in hurried escape,
Ashamed, perhaps, of their own existence,
Or maybe they know a truth I've denied.

Each droplet—a traitor—abandons its post,
Leaving me alone with the hollow ache.
Even expressions of sorrow desert me,
Evaporating like whispers to a ghost.

What loyalty can I expect from this world
When my own sadness refuses to linger?
The evidence of grief vanishes quickly,
Like promises spoken but never fulfilled.

I am learning the language of abandonment
From teachers who form within my own eyes.
Ironic that what's born from my deepest pain
Cannot bear to remain where it first arrived.

# Ephemeral Companions

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They race toward the earth, gravity's willing slaves.
Fleeting companions born in moments of anguish,
Their existence so brief, a temporary tide.

How peculiar to feel betrayed by water and salt,
These tiny reflections of an internal storm.
Created by me yet unwilling to remain,
They depart without pause, without remorse or fault.

Perhaps there's a lesson in their hasty retreat:
Nothing formed in sorrow was meant to endure.
Even the physical proof of our deepest pain
Must eventually surrender to nature's decrees.

So I'll watch them go, these disloyal friends,
And wonder if someday my grief might follow—
Slipping away just as easily, just as completely,
Leaving nothing behind but the memory of their touch.

# Forsaken Even By Sorrow

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee from my eyes like cowards from truth,
Racing down cheeks that burn with the shame
Of being abandoned by my own melancholy tide.

Is there no loyalty in this universe of pain?
When even the witnesses to my sorrow depart,
Dissipating into air, returning to nothing,
Leaving me alone to shoulder this unbearable strain.

I've become a creator of temporary things—
Breath that vanishes, words that fade, tears that desert.
Everything I produce refuses permanence,
As if my very essence commands all things to disperse.

So I stand in this desert of my own making,
Parched and yearning, yet still somehow drowning.
A paradox of existence: to overflow with emotion
Yet remain empty once the moment has passed.

# The Disloyalty of Grief

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They fall away quickly, these droplets of pain,
As if embarrassed by their own existence,
Or perhaps too heavy with the truth they hide.

Each one born from the well of my suffering,
Yet eager to depart the moment they form.
What cruel design is this—that even the symbols
Of my deepest anguish refuse to remain?

I watch them disappear into cloth, earth, and air,
Transformed and absorbed by an indifferent world.
The physical proof of my heartache vanishes,
Leaving me questioning if I ever felt at all.

Perhaps in their leaving, they carry away
Fragments of sorrow too great to contain.
Maybe their journey away from my eyes
Is mercy disguised as one final betrayal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# Abandoned by Sorrow

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like fair-weather friends,
Evaporating before they can validate my pain.
Even my grief refuses to linger,
As if my sadness isn't worthy of witness.

The salt tracks dry too quickly on my cheeks,
Leaving no evidence of this hollow aching.
My sorrow, a ghost that cannot manifest,
Denied even the physical proof of existence.

How strange to be forsaken by your own expressions,
To have the language of your body desert you.
I reach for the comfort of release
Only to find that release itself has fled,
Leaving me alone in the desert of my despair.

Perhaps tears know better than to drown with me.
Perhaps they are wiser in their swift departure.
Still, I long for the company of my own weeping,
For something to bear witness to this pain
That lives inside me, constant and unheard.

# Liquid Deserters

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down cheeks like children fleeing home,
Eager to escape the source of their creation.
What loyalty can I expect from water
When even the ocean abandons its shores twice daily?

These droplets—my only evidence of feeling—
Betraying me with their hasty departure,
Sinking into fabric, evaporating into air,
Leaving me alone with the hollow echo
Of emotions too vast for their brief existence.

Is there nothing in this world that remains?
Not even the salt-water proof of my breaking?
My body creates these messengers of grief
Only to watch them vanish without trace,
As if ashamed to be associated with my pain.

Perhaps I should learn from these liquid deserters—
How to flow away from suffering,
How to disappear without explanation,
How to refuse to be contained by the vessel
That insists on producing more of what it cannot keep.

# Ephemeral Witnesses

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They fall like shooting stars—brief, brilliant, gone.
Traitors of the highest order, these droplets
Born from the deepest wells of my anguish,
Yet so quick to depart their maker.

What use is this salt-water language
If it refuses to testify to my suffering?
Evaporating evidence, disappearing alibis,
Leaving me to wonder if I felt anything at all
Or merely imagined the weight crushing my chest.

Even my body conspires against its truth,
Producing witnesses that flee the scene.
The crime of my heartbreak left unsolved,
With nothing but damp sleeves and puffy eyes
To suggest something meaningful occurred.

Perhaps there is wisdom in their departure—
These tears teaching me through abandonment
That nothing, not even our most honest expressions,
Can be expected to remain when gravity
And the thirsty air claim everything in time.

# The Desertion of Grief

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They journey away on gravity's cruel current,
Ashamed perhaps of their salty existence,
Or eager to join some greater body of water
Where individual sorrows lose their names.

How strange to feel abandoned by my own expression,
To watch the physical form of my pain
Dissipate into nothingness, leaving no trace
That I had ever broken open at all.
Am I so easily erased?

Even the evidence of suffering refuses me company.
I am left with nothing but the memory of wetness,
The ghost-sensation of tracks down my face,
And this hollow emptiness that neither fills nor empties,
But simply exists, unwitnessed and unproven.

Perhaps I should tattoo my cheeks with permanent rivers,
Force my grief to make a lasting mark,
Demand recognition from a world that allows
Even the most honest parts of ourselves
To vanish without ceremony or farewell.

# Transient Companions

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
Fleeting companions born in anguish,
They make their swift exodus down flushed cheeks,
Departing without goodbyes or explanations,
As if my sorrow isn't worth their lingering.

What strange betrayal—to be abandoned
By the very manifestation of my pain.
Even my body's truth-tellers desert me,
Leaving no evidence of their brief existence
Beyond the salt-crusted remnants on my skin.

Is nothing faithful in this world of impermanence?
Not even the liquid language of my breaking heart?
They fall, these transparent traitors,
Racing toward oblivion with such urgency
As if bearing secrets too heavy to hold.

Perhaps there's wisdom in their hasty retreat—
Teaching me that grief itself is transitory,
That even the purest expression of our suffering
Must eventually surrender to gravity's pull,
Leaving us empty, dry, and strangely lighter.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# Abandoned by Tears

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like fair-weather friends,
Evaporating before they can validate my pain.
Even my sorrow refuses to witness itself.

Empty ducts and hollow chest,
I am a desert begging for rain
that disappears before touching sand.
My grief, so vast it scares away its own expression.

What loneliness is this—
to be forsaken by your own salt and water?
The universe denies me even the ceremony of weeping,
stealing droplets before they can chart paths down my face.

Perhaps sadness too pure for physical form
must remain invisible, a ghost of feeling
that haunts the chambers of my heart
without leaving evidence behind.

I cry into the void and the void
absorbs everything, even the proof
that I tried to release what hurts.
Not even my tears remain loyal to my pain.

# Betrayed by Sorrow

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down cheeks flushed with abandonment,
disappearing into the collar of my shirt—
small translucent deserters.

How fitting that even expressions of grief
refuse to linger, to bear witness.
They fall away like everyone else,
leaving no evidence of their brief existence.

I've become accustomed to departures:
footsteps fading, doors closing, phones silent.
But I thought at least my sorrow
would remain faithful in its wetness.

Instead, it evaporates too quickly,
leaving salt trails that itch and fade,
no puddles to reflect my broken face,
no dampness to validate what I feel.

Perhaps this is mercy—
the body refusing to keep records
of its own collapse, erasing proof
of weakness almost as it forms.

Still, I long for evidence.
Some testament to this ache.
Even my tears betray me,
vanishing like everything else I've loved.

# Ephemeral Mourning

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like thieves with pockets full of grief,
leaving me empty-handed in the aftermath of feeling.
Even liquid sorrow refuses my company.

Gravity pulls them earthward,
away from the source of their creation.
Is this the natural order of things—
that everything must fall away?

I envy those whose pain makes puddles,
whose anguish leaves visible stains.
Mine disappears without ceremony,
absorbed by the thirsty universe.

Perhaps I should collect them in jars,
these fleeting witnesses to my undoing.
At least then I could point and say,
"See? This is how much it hurt."

But they vanish too quickly for capture,
these translucent betrayers, these salt-water cowards.
Leaving me with red eyes and dry cheeks,
the only evidence a slight taste of salt on my lips.

Even in mourning, I stand abandoned.
Even in expression, I remain unwitnessed.
I cry, and cry, and cry,
but nothing remains to prove it.

# Dissolution

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon ship at the first sign of breaking,
racing toward earth as if my face burns them,
as if my cheeks are too scorched for comfort.

What loyalty can I expect from water and salt?
Elements return to elements—
back to the cycle of evaporation and rain,
indifferent to the emotions that birthed them.

Still, it feels like betrayal
when the physical proof of my pain
refuses to linger, to testify
to the storm raging behind my ribs.

I am left with nothing but dry heaves of grief,
the ghost-sensation of wetness already gone,
the memory of release without evidence.
Even my body conspires against remembering.

Perhaps this is wisdom—
the world teaching me that nothing stays,
that even manifestations of sorrow must depart,
that clinging only prolongs the suffering.

Yet I wish, just once,
my tears would remain as faithful companions,
witnesses to the undoing of my heart,
proof that I am still capable of feeling.

# Faithless Waters

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They slip away like promises never meant to be kept,
tracing momentary paths before disappearing,
leaving no evidence of their brief existence.

How strange to be abandoned by your own sorrow,
to watch it desert you mid-expression,
as if even grief finds you unworthy of its presence,
as if sadness itself has better places to be.

I press fingers to cheeks expecting dampness
but find only the ghost of what was there.
My body manufactures proof of pain
then erases it before the ink can dry.

Perhaps there is mercy in this quick dissolution,
this refusal of evidence to accumulate.
Yet I find myself longing for the weight of wet cheeks,
for the tangible reminder that what I feel is real.

The world takes everything eventually—
loved ones, memories, youth, and time.
But must it also steal the salt-water testimony
of a heart in the process of breaking?

I cry into the void and the void responds
by drinking my tears before they can witness themselves.
Even in sorrow, I stand alone,
abandoned by the very proof of my pain.

Manifestation of your own heartbreak—

EPHEMERAL WITNESS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.

What loyalty can I expect from water and salt

I watch them journey down my face,

Before they vanish into fabric or air,

Perhaps I should learn from these tears,
These masters of temporary presence.
To arrive fully, express completely,
Then depart without hesitation.

For what is grief but a passing storm?
What is pain but a moment's flash?
Even as I reach to catch them,
My tears teach me the art of letting go.

DESERTION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like cowards from a losing battle,
Dripping down to stain the collar of my shirt
Or vanish into the thirsty air.

Even the physical evidence of my sorrow
Refuses to keep me company.
Is my grief so unbearable
That even salt water seeks escape?

I've become a factory of abandonment,
Producing witnesses that immediately desert me.
My body betrays itself with each teardrop,
Creating companions that won't remain.

How strange to feel so full of something
That so quickly becomes nothing at all.
These liquid children of my anguish
Survive only seconds before their deaths.

Perhaps there's a lesson in their hasty departure—
Pain itself is meant to flow through us, not linger.
But unlike tears that dry and disappear,
The hollow spaces they leave behind remain.

TRANSIENT COMPANIONS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down my face in silent rebellion,
Eager to escape the prison of my sorrow,

My body produces these small oceans
Only to watch them evaporate into memory.
Even the physical manifestation of my pain
Lacks the courage to remain present.

I wonder where tears go when they leave us—
Do they join the clouds to fall again
On someone else's cheek? Or do they
Dissolve completely, like forgotten promises?

Perhaps they carry pieces of our heartache
Back to the universal reservoir of grief,
Where all human suffering mingles
In a vast, invisible communion.

I envy their freedom to depart,

LIQUID DESERTERS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.

I've become an unwilling alchemist,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
I Hunted Words Of Skill

With bow of thought and arrows dipped in ink,
I hunted words of skill through forests deep,
Where meanings hide and clever phrases sleep,
Pursued them to the very brink
Of understanding's precipice.

They darted swift through thickets of the mind,
Elusive prey with feathers made of sound,
I tracked their footprints on the dusty ground
Of ancient texts where wisdom's been enshrined,
And waited patiently to strike.

Each capture brought a trophy to my page,
A gleaming jewel of perfect utterance,
Strung together in a wild dance
Of syntax, rhythm, meter, rage—
A necklace fit for poet-kings.

Yet still I hunt, for words are never tamed,
They breed in silence, multiply in dreams,
And flow like never-ending streams
Of possibility, untamed,
And I, forever tracking skill.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

Through libraries vast as oceans wide,
I hunted words of skill with hungry eyes.
Parchment forests, where knowledge lies
In wait for those who dare to stride
Beyond the bounds of common speech.

With nets of curiosity I caught
The darting silver fish of metaphor,
The sturdy beasts of prose I long sought for,
The nimble birds of verse that can't be bought
With anything but patience, time.

My fingers calloused from the chase,
My mind expanded by the hunt itself,
Each captured word placed careful on the shelf
Of memory, creating space
For newer, rarer specimens.

And when the moon replaced the sun,
I'd count my treasures, polish them with care,
Arrange them in formations rare and fair,
To show what beauty could be spun
From words I hunted with such skill.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill in twilight hours
When consciousness and dreaming intertwine.
With traps of thought and reason's careful line,
I sought expressions with transcendent powers
To elevate the mundane into art.

Through dictionaries thick with dusty terms,
Across the plains of languages long dead,
I tracked the footprints where the masters led,
Unearthed the seeds from which all meaning germs,
And planted them in fertile soil of verse.

Sometimes the prey escaped my grasp,
The perfect phrase evading capture's hold,
More precious than refined and burnished gold,
Leaving me breathless with a desperate gasp,
Determined more to catch it next attempt.

This hunt continues through my days,
A lifetime's quest for verbal alchemy,
Transforming thought to word, to poetry,
Illuminating life's mysterious ways
With words I've hunted, words of skill.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

With lantern lit by inspiration's flame,
I hunted words of skill through darkened halls
Of consciousness, where echo calls
Resounded with each whispered name
Of adjective and verb and noun.

The quarry swift, elusive as the wind,
Darted between the shadows of my thought.
Each syllable so desperately sought
Left traces for my mind to find
Along the pathways of expression.

Some words I snared were wild and fierce,
Untamed by common usage, raw with power.
Some gentle as a morning's dew-kissed flower,
Some sharp enough the heart to pierce,
All gathered in my hunter's bag.

At day's end by the fireside I sat,
Examining my treasures one by one,
Arranging them until their meaning spun
A tapestry of thought, and after that,
I knew the hunt had made me skilled.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill across the plains
Of blank white pages, trackless as new snow,
Where only those with patient hearts may go
To seek the language that remains
Uncaptured by the common tongue.

Armed with the weapons of attention keen,
I stalked through dictionaries' tangled growth,
Past thesaurus thickets, nothing loath
To wade through grammar streams unseen
By those who hunt for lesser prey.

Sometimes at dawn I'd catch a phrase
Surprised in morning's vulnerable light,
Or track a metaphor through starry night,
Until, emerging from the haze,
It stood revealed in perfect form.

My trophy wall now bears the heads
Of captured concepts, mounted with such care,
Each one unique, each one beyond compare.
Yet still I rise from restless beds
To hunt more words of greater skill.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

seeking a voice through which
to sing their ancient songs.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill
Through dictionaries vast as oceans,
Through memories thin as air,
Seeking perfect expressions
For emotions beyond compare.

I tracked them down dark alleys of thought,
Through bright meadows of inspiration,
Some came willingly, some fought,
Against their own creation.

Words of amber, words of steel,
Words that make the senses reel,
Words that wound and words that heal,
All precious in their own appeal.

I gathered them like fallen stars,
Each one unique in luminosity,
Arranged them in patterns near and far,
A constellation of my curiosity.

Now they hunt me in return,
Chasing through my dreams at night,
Whispering secrets I've yet to learn—
The hunter becomes prey in morning light.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill
in the wilderness of language,
armed with nothing but desire
and the hunger to be heard.

Stalked them through the underbrush
of half-remembered phrases,
tracked their footprints in the mud
of conversations long since dried.

Some words I caught were still alive,
wriggling in my grasp like fish,
others came already preserved,
ancient and crystallized in time.

I built traps of silence,
patient spaces where meaning
might wander unsuspecting
into my waiting hands.

What I never understood:
the words were hunting me as well,
each one seeking the right voice,
the perfect vessel for its power.

In the end, we found each other,
predator and prey united,
a symbiosis of sound and soul—
neither truly captured, both transformed.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill
With nets woven from midnight thoughts
And hooks baited with raw emotion,
Casting into the deep waters of language.

Some days the catch was meager—
Trivial phrases, common expressions,
Tossed back into the current
To grow stronger, more profound.

But sometimes, in rare moments
When the moon aligned with memory,
I'd haul in something magnificent:
A metaphor that breathed like a living thing,

A simile that shimmered with truth,
A verb that danced across the page.

I mounted these trophies carefully,
Preserved them in stanzas and verses,
But never considered that perhaps
It was not I who did the hunting.

Perhaps the words sought me instead,
Lured by the beacon of my longing,
Choosing me as their sanctuary,
Their voice in a world grown silent.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill
through mountains of blank pages,
fingertips calloused from

In the dawn hours when

But the hunt changed me.

my ears attuned to the subtle

Now I wonder—was I the hunter

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I learned to track the footprints

I Hunted Words Of Skill

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
I Hunted Words Of Skill

Through forests of blank pages I stalked,
Bow drawn with fingers ink-stained and raw.
I hunted words of skill, elusive prey,
That darted between shadows of thought.

Some words flashed like silver fish in streams,
Others hid, camouflaged in memory's brush.
I tracked their footprints through the snow of doubt,
Followed their echoes in silence's hush.

My quiver filled with metaphors and rhymes,
Arrows fletched with purpose, sharp with truth.
I waited in the blind of patience built,
For language rare to show its precious tooth.

What trophies have I mounted on these walls?
Not dead things, but living thoughts that breathe,
That dance when readers' eyes fall upon them,
And weave new worlds from what my hunt bequeathed.

The Lexical Hunter

I hunted words of skill across vast plains of thought,
Armed with nothing but desire and an empty page.
Each syllable a creature, wild and untaught,
Evading capture, dancing beyond my cage.

Through thickets of confusion, I tracked their trail,
Patient as winter, hungry as spring's first bloom.
Some words came easy—docile, without fail—
While others required stalking through gloom.

I laid traps of silence, waited for them to appear,
Those perfect expressions, precise and true.
Sometimes I'd glimpse them, crystalline and clear,
Then watch them vanish like morning dew.

Yet in this hunt, the prey is never truly caught;
The words, once found, find me instead.
They make their home within my tangled thought,
And I become the hunted, spirit-led.

Wordsmith's Quest

I hunted words of skill through midnight hours,
When consciousness blurs and dreams begin to spill
Into the waking world. With patient powers,
I stalked elusive phrases, hunting still.

My weapons: pen and mind and burning need
To capture thoughts that flutter, wisps of smoke.
Each metaphor a trophy, each verse a seed
That might, with tender care, to life be woke.

The hunt led down to canyons carved by time,
Up mountains where the air grows thin and pure.
I chased the perfect cadence, sought the rhyme
That rings with truth no reader could ignore.

Some days I returned empty-handed, worn,
My traps all sprung but catching only air.
Other times the bounty left me torn—
Too much to carry home, too rich to bear.

This endless chase, this hunger never sated,
This blessing and this curse of those who write:
To be forever hunting, forever fated
To seek the words that bring the dark to light.

Lexical Expedition

I hunted words of skill in ancient tomes,
Dust-covered volumes speaking tales of old.
Through yellowed pages where wisdom roams,
I sought expressions precious more than gold.

With dictionary compass guiding me,
I crossed the syntax seas on metaphor ships.
Each adjective an island, wild and free,
Each verb a current pulling at my lips.

The rarest specimens I sought to find—
Those terms that dance with meaning, rich and deep.
Those phrases turning gently in the mind,
Like keys unlocking doors to secrets keep.

Some words I found were thorned and hard to hold,
While others bloomed like flowers in my hand.
Some burned like fire, some whispered winter cold,
Each one a creature native to its land.

Now, look upon my collection, carefully arranged,
Not mounted lifeless, but living still with breath.
A garden of expression, ever-changed,
Defying time and distance, even death.

The Word Hunter's Confession

I hunted words of skill when stars were bright,
Creeping through the underbrush of thought.
My mind a forest in the dead of night,
Where language hides and waits to be caught.

With snares of silence, traps of solitude,

The finest specimens I mounted not
